physicalObject: tall black Tesla-branded stainless steel water bottle with silver cap
proxyLocation: upper center-left of the white table in snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle exclusively by its neck right under the silver cap using a C-shape power grip. This neck section is roughly 3 cm in diameter and provides a rigid, rounded rod similar to a mug handle. Lift and tilt the bottle as you would a mug; the bottle’s steel mass and liquid inside (if any) offer a comparable moderate weight and shifting center of gravity.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This mug serves as a drinking vessel, designed to be grasped by the handle
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate weight that feels substantial since it's full. As well as a rotational moment around their grip point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a relatively thin, slender rod approximately 2 cm in diameter. User should sense the handle's curved arc and rounded cross-section.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user will approach the mug’s handle with a semi-open C-shape power grip, curling 2–3 fingers around the slender 2 cm-diameter rod while the thumb opposes from the outside. The hand closes until the handle rests against the proximal phalanges, giving a stable lever to lift. The wrist then pivots to raise the mug toward the mouth; elbow flexion provides the bulk of the lift while shoulder abducts slightly. Just before drinking, the wrist pronates and then slowly tilts the mug so the liquid flows toward the rim. Throughout the tilt the user perceives moderate liquid weight and a shifting center of mass that creates a small rotational moment around the handle. Micro-adjustments of finger force stabilize the mug against this torque. After sipping, the wrist supinates to level the mug and the arm lowers it back. If the mug is set on a surface, contact is made with the flat base first, producing a short normal impulse. The mug itself offers no compliance, so the haptic response is rigid and inert; any slosh in the liquid would be perceived only visually or through subtle controller vibration.

proxyLocation: bottom left of the white table in snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Pinch-grip one front vertical edge of the box between your thumb and two fingers so that the edge acts like a narrow handle. Lift and tilt the box as if drinking; the box’s low weight won’t fully match inertia, but the sharp rectangular edge gives a clear lever for rotational feedback around the grip point.

physicalObject: small cylindrical shiny metal calibration weight
proxyLocation: center of the white table in snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Hook the pads of your index and middle fingers over the domed top while the thumb supports under the rim, letting the weight dangle below your grip. This finger-hook posture reproduces clasping a mug’s handle and, because the weight is dense, it delivers the important sense of moderate inertia when you tilt it.

physicalObject: clear plastic jar or container (stackable design)

physicalObject: tall black Tesla-branded stainless-steel water bottle with silver cap
proxyLocation: standing upright toward the upper center-left of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Grasp the bottle low on its cylindrical body, leaving the heavy capped end pointing forward. The metal weight concentrates toward the top, so the user feels a head-heavy moment similar to an axe. Swinging the bottle in a chopping arc reproduces the forward-drooping inertia and requires the same firm, single-handed power grip around a handle-sized cylinder.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user employs a single-handed power grip, wrapping all fingers and thumb tightly around the lower portion of the cylindrical wooden handle. The grip axis aligns roughly with the forearm to maximize control. Because the head is heavy, the user feels an immediate forward/top-heavy inertia that tries to droop the blade downward. Swinging involves drawing the axe backward (elbow flexion, shoulder extension), then a rapid shoulder flexion and elbow extension to drive the blade in an arcing path. The wrist remains fairly stiff, adding a minor pronation snap just before impact. After contact with a virtual target, the head virtually decelerates abruptly, sending a simulated recoil up the handle; the user experiences this as controller vibration coupled with a torque impulse that momentarily pulls the handle out of line. If the user keeps chopping, they reset the axe by lifting it using more shoulder than wrist, repeating the cycle.

proxyLocation: lying flat near the bottom left of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Pinch one of the short, narrow edges of the box and let the larger body extend outward to simulate an over-sized axe head. While quite light, the offset mass still gives a lever feeling; users can practice the wrist-stiff, shoulder-driven chopping motion by swinging the protruding bulk.

After contact with a virtual target, the head virtually decelerates abruptly, sending a simulated recoil up the handle; the user experiences this as controller vibration coupled with a torque impulse that momentarily pulls the handle out of line. If the user keeps chopping, they reset the axe by lifting it using more shoulder than wrist, repeating the cycle.

proxyLocation: bottom left of the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Hold the pen far back near its clip, leaving the writing tip and metal ferrule projecting forward. This shifts the small amount of weight toward the tip, giving a micro-scale version of an axe’s blade-heavy feel and permitting precise practice swings focused on wrist alignment.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user employs a single-handed power grip, wrapping all fingers and thumb tightly around the lower portion of the cylindrical wooden handle. The grip axis aligns roughly with the forearm to maximize control. Because the head is heavy, the user feels an immediate forward/top-heavy inertia that tries to droop the blade downward. Swinging involves drawing the axe backward (elbow flexion, shoulder extension), then a rapid shoulder flexion and elbow extension to drive the blade in an arcing path. The wrist remains fairly stiff, adding a minor pronation snap just before impact. After contact with a virtual target, the head virtually decelerates abruptly, sending a simulated recoil up the handle; the user experiences this as controller vibration coupled with a torque impulse that momentarily pulls the handle out of line. If the user keeps chopping, they reset the axe by lifting it using more shoulder than wrist, repeating the cycle.

physicalObject: black telescopic selfie stick with adjustable phone holder
proxyLocation: upper left of the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Collapse the telescopic pole halfway, grip the padded handle at its very end, and keep the phone clamp extended forward. The clamp and partially extended metal shaft pull the center of mass away from your hand, closely mimicking an axe’s head-heavy leverage. Full shoulder-driven chopping arcs feel convincing thanks to the length, diameter, and distributed weight.

physicalObject: tall black Tesla-branded stainless steel water bottle with silver cap
proxyLocation: standing upright near the rear-left of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Grasp the bottle a few centimetres above its base so the bulk of the filled bottle (or even its empty but still metal heft) sits above your fist. The cylindrical lower section supplies the correct fist-sized handle while the mass above the hand gives a clear head-heavy feel. Swing the bottle downward in a vertical arc; the cap region becomes the striking face, reproducing the momentum shift and weight distribution of a hammer.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The hammer is grasped in a power grip similar to the axe, but higher up on the handle to shorten the lever for better control. The head-heavy inertia is instantly apparent, urging the head to dip. Typical use is a vertical pounding motion: the user raises the hammer by flexing the elbow and shoulder, then rapidly extends the elbow and drops the shoulder while keeping the wrist locked, delivering the head straight downward. Upon virtual impact, the hammer head stops suddenly; the user detects a sharp vibration plus a brief upward reactive force, imitating the rebound of a dense object (e.g., striking a nail or anvil). For precision strikes, users may choke up on the handle, sliding the hand closer to the head to reduce swing arc and torque.

proxyLocation: lying flat at the front-left of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Slip one hand under one short edge so that your fingers curl around the box like a thick, blocky handle. The broad, weighty slab above your knuckles imitates an oversized hammer head. Although lighter than a real hammer, the large planar surface gives clear feedback when you bring it down onto another surface, letting you rehearse the pounding gesture and abrupt stop on impact.

physicalObject: tall black Tesla-branded stainless-steel water bottle
proxyLocation: standing upright near the rear left of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Grip the bottle around its neck just below the silver cap; this narrow cylindrical portion mimics the short sickle handle. Let the heavier body of the bottle project forward and slightly downward to represent the curved blade’s mass. Perform the same sweeping, wrist-led pull—its weight produces a modest forward inertia comparable to the virtual blade.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The sickle is held with a power-pinch hybrid: the fingers wrap around the short cylindrical handle while the thumb presses along the side, allowing blade orientation control. The forearm is pronated so the curved blade faces forward/outward. A typical cut begins with the wrist slightly extended and the elbow flexed. The user then performs a sweeping pull: shoulder abducts minimally, elbow extends a bit, and the wrist flexes while the forearm supinates, drawing the blade in a concave path that hooks and slices through virtual vegetation. Because the curved blade mass is distributed along its arc, the user feels a modest forward inertia but less concentrated than an axe. On contact, the blade drags through material, producing continuous low-frequency vibration and gentle resistance rather than a single impact jolt. After the follow-through, the user resets by rotating the wrist back and bringing the sickle forward for another stroke.

proxyLocation: lying flat at the front left edge of the table
utilizationMethod: Pinch one of the short side flaps between thumb and fingers as a makeshift handle while the bulk of the box extends outward. Although very light, the flat face gives visual/kinesthetic reference for the sickle’s sweeping plane; swing the box in the same hooking motion to practice reach and elbow/wrist coordination.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The sickle is held with a power-pinch hybrid: the fingers wrap around the short cylindrical handle while the thumb presses along the side, allowing blade orientation control. The forearm is pronated so the curved blade faces forward/outward. A typical cut begins with the wrist slightly extended and the elbow flexed. The user then performs a sweeping pull: shoulder abducts minimally, elbow extends a bit, and the wrist flexes while the forearm supinates, drawing the blade in a concave path that hooks and slices through virtual vegetation. Because the curved blade mass is distributed along its arc, the user feels a modest forward inertia but less concentrated than an axe. On contact, the blade drags through material, producing continuous low-frequency vibration and gentle resistance rather than a single impact jolt. After the follow-through, the user resets by rotating the wrist back and bringing the sickle forward for another stroke.

proxyLocation: mid-right of the yellow table in snapshot 2
utilizationMethod: Grip the dongle by its short USB-C plug between thumb and forefinger (acting as the sickle handle) while the rectangular housing projects forward like a miniature blade. Rotate the wrist to rehearse precise orientation control.

proxyLocation: bottom left of the yellow table in snapshot 2
utilizationMethod: Hold the pen near its rear cap so that the writing tip curves forward, mimicking the sickle’s cutting edge. The cylindrical barrel reproduces the correct grip geometry, and flicking motions with the pen let the user feel handle rotation and blade follow-through.

physicalObject: black telescopic selfie stick with phone holder
proxyLocation: upper left of the yellow table in snapshot 3
utilizationMethod: Hold the rubberized black grip as the sickle handle; extend a single telescope segment so the rod plus phone clamp form a curved, forward-projecting mass. The distributed weight along the rod closely mirrors a sickle blade, allowing full-scale elbow and wrist sweeps that replicate harvesting strokes.

proxyLocation: upper right of the yellow table in snapshot 3
utilizationMethod: Wrap fingers around one of the controller’s handgrips, treating it as the sickle’s short handle while the bulk of the controller extends outward like the blade arc. The controller’s mass gives moderate inertia, and its curved silhouette helps guide the concave slicing path.

proxyLocation: bottom centre of the yellow table in snapshot 3
utilizationMethod: Pinch the metal audio jack as the handle and let the coiled cable hang in a natural arc that visually suggests the sickle blade. Swinging the lightweight cable allows safe, sweeping practice of the hook-and-pull motion, with the slack cable providing subtle drag similar to slicing through soft vegetation.
